status_details: Gov. Mike Dunleavy, a Republican, eased restrictions on several kinds of businesses starting April 24. Alaska became one of the first states to make a nearly complete reopening, with all businesses allowed to open at full capacity on May 22.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Kay Ivey, a Republican, ordered residents to stay home for much of April and began reopening businesses May 1. Since May 22, Alabama has been in a second stage of “Safer at Home,” with capacity limits on businesses and some gatherings. With cases rising, Ms. Ivey extended those guidelines until the end of July.
opened_personal_care: Salons
opened_entertainment: Entertainment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, never implemented a statewide stay-at-home order, instead opting to close high-contact businesses like gyms and personal care services. The state began reopening many of these in early May and raised capacity limits for many sectors in mid-June. Arkansas has seen one of the steepest increases in coronavirus cases since its reopening began.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Theaters, stadiums, museums, bowling alleys; Casinos; Large venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Doug Ducey, a Republican, began gradually reopening businesses in early May. After his stay-at-home order expired May 15, Arizona saw cases soar. In response, on June 29, Mr. Ducey announced that the state would “pause” operations of bars, gyms, movie theaters, waterparks and tubing rentals for one month to contain the virus’s spread.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools, spas

date_details: Stay-at-home order in effect since March 19.
status_details: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, has emphasized caution and allowed counties to reopen sectors only as they meet certain criteria for testing and transmission rates. Many California counties reopened businesses such as restaurants and personal care services in May. In response to rising case counts in recent weeks, the state has created a “watch list” of counties where bars, indoor dining and other indoor activities must close until the virus’s spread is controlled.
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining in some counties; Bars in some counties
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Hair salons and barbershops in some counties; Nail salons, cosmetology services, tattoo parlors, piercing shops in some counties
opened_entertainment: Casinos in some counties; Museums, galleries, zoos, aquariums in some counties; Bowling alleys, arcades, mini golf, theaters in some counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms in some counties
opened_industries: Manufacturing; Warehouses; Offices; Movie, TV and music production

status_details: Gov. Jared Polis was one of the first Democratic governors to begin reopening his state, letting Colorado's stay-at-home order expire on April 26. Businesses reopened throughout May and June, but in response to continuing outbreaks in neighboring states, on July 1, Mr. Polis extended the state’s Safer at Home phase and closed bars. Counties and communities that meet certain criteria could reopen bars or move further along in reopening later this month.
opened_personal_care: Salons and personal services
opened_entertainment: Museums, indoor events; Fairs, rodeos, concerts, outdoor events; Libraries
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Pools, playgrounds; Gyms

status_details: Connecticut was one of the last states to begin reopening, as Gov. Ned Lamont, a Democrat, allowed the state’s stay-at-home order to expire on May 20. A second phase of reopening was moved up in June after a favorable downward trend in case numbers. But Mr. Lamont postponed a third phase, which would have reopened bars and increased capacity limits for reopened businesses, in response to rising cases in neighboring states.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons; Tattoo parlors, spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries; Amusement parks, bowling alleys
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms; State campgrounds

status_details: Washington, D.C., was under one of the nation’s strictest lockdowns until Mayor Muriel Bowser, a Democrat, began reopening on May 29, lifting a stay-at-home order before it was scheduled to expire. On June 22, she opened a second round of businesses.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons; Nail salons, waxing salons, spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Dog parks, golf courses, tennis courts, parks; Gyms

date_details: Shelter in place expired on May 31.
status_details: Gov. John Carney, a Democrat, has overseen one of the slower reopenings, beginning June 1 with a limited number of businesses. Delaware moved into a second phase on June 15. After an increase in cases, Mr. Carney decided to delay the start of Phase 3, which was scheduled for the end of June.
opened_food_and_drink: Farmers markets; Restaurants; Bars in some areas
opened_personal_care: Barber shops, hair salons, tanning salons; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries, galleries, live performances; Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Pools; Gyms; Campgrounds

status_details: Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, gradually opened businesses in May, starting in Florida’s less populous counties. In early June, he moved forward with reopening bars and larger entertainment venues in some counties, even as case counts rose. On June 26, he moved to effectively shutter bars again after a spike in cases.
opened_personal_care: Salons; Tattoo parlors, massage therapy, tanning salons, acupuncture in most counties
opened_entertainment: Sporting venues without spectators; Museums, libraries; Movie theaters, concert halls, bowling alleys in most counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, trails; Gyms

date_details: Shelter in place expired on April 30.
status_details: Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, went toe-to-toe with the White House and local mayors over his decision to reopen large parts of Georgia’s economy ahead of other states, starting April 24. Mr. Kemp has continued steadily with the state’s reopening plans while case counts have trended upward.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys; Theaters, private social clubs; Large venues; Bars, nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms

status_details: Gov. David Ige, a Democrat, started the state’s reopening process in early May, when there were only a few new cases reported each day. Each island can now set its own timeline for reopening, with the governor’s approval. Despite the slow approach, Hawaii has seen a resurgence of the virus in recent days.
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Nail salons in some areas; Tattoo parlors in some areas; Salons and barbershops
opened_entertainment: Arcades, bowling alleys, theaters in some areas
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, piers, docks, etc.; State parks; Pools and waterparks in some areas; Campgrounds in some areas; Gyms
opened_industries: Construction in some areas; Offices in some areas

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Kim Reynolds, a Republican, ordered a number of businesses closed beginning March 17, but resisted calls to issue a stay-at-home order. Ms. Reynolds loosened restrictions in 77 of the state’s 99 counties starting May 1, and in all counties on May 15. Capacity limits on businesses were lifted June 10.
opened_personal_care: Medical spas, tanning salons; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Movie theaters; Museums, zoos, aquariums; Casinos; Outdoor venues; Bowling alleys, amusement parks; Indoor venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools; Playgrounds, skating rinks, skate parks

status_details: Gov. Brad Little, a Republican, began his state’s four-stage reopening process on May 1. Idaho moved through the first three stages of reopening swiftly, but as cases surged, Mr. Little delayed a full reopening planned for June 26. After a two-week delay, on July 9, he announced the state would remain in its final stage of reopening for at least another two weeks.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Nightclubs; Large venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools and water parks

status_details: Gov. J.B. Pritzker, a Democrat, faced political pushback for his cautious reopening strategy, but Illinois has not seen a strong upward trend in cases. On June 26, the state moved into its fourth and final stage of reopening.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming; Hair salons, barber shops, nail salons, spas, waxing centers, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Theaters
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; limited fishing, boating, golf courses; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Eric Holcomb, a Republican, eased restrictions and allowed some reopenings for most of the state beginning May 4. On July 1,  Mr. Holcomb announced that the state would pause progression to its fifth and final stage of reopening due to an increase in cases statewide and nationally. The final phase would have removed capacity limits on businesses.
opened_personal_care: Spas, salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
closed_entertainment: Conventions, fairs, parades and similar events
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Museums, zoos and aquariums; Venues; Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Conventions, fairs, parades and similar events in most counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools, tennis and basketball courts; Campgrounds; Amusement parks, water parks

status_details: After reopening began May 4, Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, faced backlash from Republicans in the state legislature who wanted the process to move more quickly. She vetoed a measure seeking to curb her emergency powers, and allowed reopenings at the discretion of individual counties. Ms. Kelly ordered Kansans to wear masks in public beginning July 3.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums and bowling alleys; Casinos; Nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Community centers, sports facilities; Pools

date_details: Healthy at home in effect since March 26.
status_details: Gov. Andy Beshear, a Democrat, reopened businesses under new guidelines beginning in early May. The state has come to the end of its initial reopening timeline, though gatherings are still limited to 50 or fewer people and Mr. Beshear has ordered residents to wear masks in public.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums, aquariums, libraries, outdoor attractions; Venues and events spaces
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Aquatic centers; Campgrounds; Public pools

status_details: Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, allowed the state’s stay-at-home order to lift and an array of businesses to reopen starting May 15, after facing mounting pressure to reopen from the Republican-controlled state legislature. The state moved into the second phase of its reopening plan on June 5. On June 22, citing an increase in cases, Mr. Edwards announced that the state would remain in Phase 2 for several more weeks.
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Spas, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Certain museums, zoos and aquariums; Casinos; Event centers
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks; Pools; Bowling alleys, skating rinks
closed_outdoor_and_recreation: Amusement parks, water parks and theme parks; Concert and music halls

status_details: Gov. Charlie Baker, a Republican, announced a phased reopening beginning in May, with four stages scheduled to last three weeks apiece. On July 2, Mr. Baker announced that the state would progress to Phase 3 on July 6, with the exception of Boston.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Pet grooming; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons
closed_entertainment: Movie theaters; Museums and aquariums; Amusement parks, water parks and theme parks; Theaters and performance halls; Ballrooms, stadiums and convention halls
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys in most regions; Museums, aquariums in most regions; Theaters and performance venues in most regions; Movie theaters in most regions; Casinos in most regions
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Beaches, parks, fishing, hunting and boating; Gyms in most regions

status_details: Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican who has called for an aggressive response to the virus, allowed some businesses to open with social distancing requirements starting May 15, but encouraged the adoption of more restrictive guidelines at the local level as needed. The decision to allow further reopenings in mid-June was met with criticism from a top health adviser.
opened_food_and_drink: Outdoor service at breweries, wineries, and distilleries; Restaurants; Bars
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, outdoor shooting ranges, marinas, campgrounds; Beaches; Outdoor pools and day camps; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Janet Mills, a Democrat, allowed some personal care businesses to begin reopening statewide May 1 and allowed additional, accelerated reopenings in counties with few coronavirus cases. More businesses were allowed to reopen statewide on June 1, but further reopenings, including of bars, have been delayed.
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurants; Bars open for outdoor service
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Nail salons and tattoo parlors; Spas and massage parlors
opened_entertainment: Amusement parks, water parks; Bowling alleys and arcades; Movie theaters; Performing arts venues; Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, boating, golf courses; Remote campgrounds, hunting and fishing; Private campgrounds, RV parks; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, took a regional approach to reopening before lifting a statewide stay-at-home order on June 1. Some businesses were allowed to reopen statewide beginning June 8. Ms. Whitmer has since paused further statewide reopenings, and on July 1, she ordered bars in most of the state to close again for indoor service. Ms. Whitmer has since mandated the use of masks in most public settings.
opened_food_and_drink: Bars for indoor service in certain counties; Restaurant dining; Bars for outdoor service
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Arcades, bowling alleys, theaters, night clubs and convention centers in some regions
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas; Pools; Gyms in some regions
opened_industries: Construction, real estate; Manufacturing, including auto companies; Offices
closed_food_and_drink: Bars for indoor service in certain counties

status_details: Gov. Tim Walz, a Democrat, first allowed employees in certain agriculture, industrial and office settings to return to work starting April 27. More businesses were allowed to open at reduced capacity after his stay-at-home order expired in May.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Theaters and concert halls; Bowling alleys, arcades and museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, reopened all businesses — including large venues, concerts and movie theaters — on May 4, with social distancing requirements. Mr. Parson later announced that the state would lift all restrictions on June 16. Since then, Missouri has seen several record-setting single-day increases in coronavirus cases.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, music venues, etc.; Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Campgrounds

date_details: Shelter in place expired on April 27.
status_details: Gov. Tate Reeves, a Republican, let the state’s stay-at-home order expire April 27 and reopened retail stores, with some limits. All businesses were allowed to open June 1. In July, Mr. Reeves announced that the state would pause a full reopening, and he later placed additional restrictions on 13 counties, mandating the use of masks in public and limiting social gatherings. But he stopped short of ordering businesses to close again.
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries, museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Steve Bullock, a Democrat, allowed reopening in phases, beginning in late April. Montana is one of the few states where schools had the option to reopen this academic year, and a few schools began to reopen May 7. All businesses could reopen June 1, provided they followed certain guidelines.
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining, bars, breweries and distilleries
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, massage parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums, movie theaters; Concert venues; Bowling alleys; Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms

status_details: Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, allowed a variety of businesses to reopen in May. In late June, with cases counts trending upward, Mr. Cooper paused North Carolina’s reopening plan and required residents to wear face coverings in public. On July 7, a judge sided with bowling alleys in a legal battle challenging Mr. Cooper’s plan and ruled that they could reopen. Mr. Cooper said he will appeal the ruling.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Doug Burgum, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order, and allowed a variety of businesses to reopen starting May 1.
opened_personal_care: Salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Music and entertainment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Sports venues

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Pete Ricketts, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order, but he put in place several restrictions on businesses. Mr. Ricketts announced a plan to reopen certain businesses on a regional basis starting May 4, followed by all counties on June 1. Most of the state moved into Phase 3 of reopening in late June.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Zoos, movie theaters, libraries and venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Chris Sununu, a Republican, gradually reopened sectors starting in mid-May. On June 15, he allowed his stay-at-home order to expire and reopened businesses on a rolling basis since. The final round of businesses reopened, with capacity limits and social distancing guidance, on June 29.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons, etc.; Nail salons; Tanning salons; Tattoo shops; Acupuncturists and massage therapists
opened_entertainment: Libraries, museums, art galleries; Bowling alleys and entertainment centers; Movie theaters; Amusement parks; Live performances

status_details: Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, was one of the last governors to lift a stay-at-home order, on June 9. New Jersey cautiously reopened businesses over the course of May and June, and rolling reopenings were set to continue into July, though Mr. Murphy indefinitely delayed plans to reopen indoor dining.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, spas, massage therapy, tanning salons
opened_entertainment: Libraries for curbside pickup; Casinos; Playgrounds, water parks, amusement parks; Museums, libraries, aquariums; Bowling alleys, batting cages, shooting ranges

status_details: Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, extended New Mexico’s stay-at-home order through the end of May but allowed some sectors to reopen at limited capacities beginning May 16. Three northwestern counties with the most severe outbreaks were shut down until June 1. The next phase of reopenings is delayed indefinitely. Ms. Grisham ordered restaurants to once again restrict indoor dining beginning July 13.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding, veterinary services; Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage parlors, nail salons
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Golf courses, boating; Gyms, pools

status_details: Gov. Steve Sisolak, a Democrat, kept pace with other states and reopened many businesses starting May 9. Casinos and gaming were allowed to resume operations on June 4. In response to a recent spike in cases, Mr. Sisolak tabled plans for Phase 3, closed bars in some counties, and required Nevadans to wear face masks.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons and nail salons; Massage therapy; Tattoo and piercing shops
opened_entertainment: Museums, art galleries, zoos and aquariums; Movie theaters, bowling alleys; Gaming
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, pickleball, tennis courts; State parks; Gyms; Pools and water parks

status_details: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, announced limited and phased reopenings by region starting May 15. Most of the state is now in the fourth stage of reopening, and malls were allowed to open beginning July 10. New York City is in a modified third stage, where indoor dining at restaurants remains prohibited.
opened_food_and_drink: Outdoor dining at restaurants in some regions; Indoor dining in some regions
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Tattoo parlors, massage parlors, nail salons

status_details: Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, lifted a stay-at-home order on May 1 and issued a “Stay Safe Ohio Order” that allowed businesses to reopen in phases, starting with retail stores, salons and restaurants. In early July, Mr. DeWine asked 12 counties to limit activities as much as possible, though he did not order any closures. People in those counties are now required to wear face masks in public.

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Kevin Stitt, a Republican, implemented a three-phase approach to reopening businesses starting April 24. Phase 3 began in June, when all restrictions were lifted on businesses and group gatherings provided people “consider social distancing.”
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, spas, pet groomers, etc.; Tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, sports venues, museums; Nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Zoos; Gyms

date_details: Stay-at-home order in effect since March 23.
status_details: Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat, started a three-phase regional reopening on May 15. All but four counties have now entered the second phase, but Ms. Brown said Phase 3 would not come until September at the earliest. Eigh counties are on a watch list and could see businesses close if cases increase.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, bowling alleys in most counties

status_details: Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, took a county-by-county approach to shutting down, before issuing a statewide stay-at-home order on April 1. He is taking a similar approach to reopening, allowing counties to open in phases. By July 3, all of the state was in the last phase of reopening, but wearing a mask is now required in all public places.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, spas
opened_entertainment: Casinos, theaters
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas, private campgrounds; Beaches; State parks; Public pools; Gyms

date_details: Curfew in effect since March 15 and set to expire July 22.
status_details: Gov. Wanda Vázquez, a member of the New Progressive Party, announced a curfew and closed non-essential businesses in March. Restaurants and retail stores were allowed to reopen in late May. In mid-June, Ms. Vázquez eased the lockdown and allowed most businesses to reopen, though she said she would reimpose restrictions if residents did not follow social distancing guidelines.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops; Pet grooming; Spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, movie theaters; Outdoor concerts and other open venues

status_details: Gov. Gina Raimondo, a Democrat, announced a three-phase reopening plan starting with retail stores after her stay-at-home order lifted on May 8. Rhode Island entered its second phase of reopening in June, with restaurants, gyms, salons and beaches allowed to open. The third phase was set to begin June 30, though the governor decided to limit indoor social gatherings to 25 people.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tattoo shops
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Beaches; Gyms; Casinos; Campgrounds

status_details: Gov. Henry McMaster, a Republican, was among the last to issue a stay-at-home order and among the first to begin opening up his state, starting April 20. The reopening began with retail stores and continued in the following weeks with restaurants, gyms and pools. Tourist attractions reopened in time for Memorial Day weekend. But with cases rising, Mr. McMaster said he wouldn’t allow movie theaters, concerts, race tracks or nightclubs to open.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Kristi Noem, a Republican, refused to issue a stay-at-home order — despite requests from local officials — and did not close businesses in the state, though she ordered them to follow C.D.C. guidelines. She invited workers and business owners frustrated by lockdowns in other states to visit South Dakota.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops

status_details: Gov. Bill Lee, a Republican, announced reopening plans for 89 of 95 Tennessee counties starting April 27. The remaining counties were to follow individual reopening plans. All counties are now in some phase of reopening, and restaurants and retail stores can operate in most counties with no restrictions.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums, amusement parks

status_details: Gov. Greg Abbott allowed his stay-at-home order to lapse on April 30, a move that gave Texas, the nation’s second-largest state, one of the shortest such orders in the country. A surge in cases in late June caused Mr. Abbott to order bars to close and restaurants to reduce capacity, among the first reopening reversals in the country. Starting July 3, he once again encouraged Texans to stay home and required face covering in public places in counties with more than 20 positive cases.

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Gary R. Herbert, a Republican, started to reopen Utah by region on May 1. Now, just one county remains at “moderate risk,” and restaurants, gyms and salons are open everywhere.

status_details: Gov. Ralph Northam, a Democrat, started reopening much of the state on May 15, but kept northern Virginia, near Washington, D.C., closed until May 28. All counties moved into Phase 3 on July 1. Mr. Northam lifted capacity limits on retail stores, restaurants and bars, but kept some restrictions on indoor seating in place.

status_details: Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, said he would not hesitate to pause reopenings or close businesses if needed. While every county has now moved into some phase of reopening, Washington said it would pause before moving any counties into Phase 4 and keep restrictions in place through July 9. Mr. Inslee also ordered businesses to require employees and customers to wear face masks and prohibited bar seating and live music in most counties.

date_details: Stay-at-home order struck down on May 13.
status_details: The state Supreme Court struck down Gov. Tony Evers's stay-at-home order on May 13, effectively lifting statewide restrictions on businesses in Wisconsin. Mr. Evers, a Democrat in a highly contested battleground state, had already announced plans for a gradual reopening but warned the ruling would cause “chaos.” Some counties have since placed their own restrictions on businesses.
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers for curbside dropoff; Hair salons, spas, barbershops
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; State parks; Gyms

status_details: West Virginia’s stay-at-home order was in place for a little more than a month. Gov. Jim Justice, a Republican, lifted restrictions on certain businesses on May 4, with new reopenings each following week. Houses of worship were among the first allowed to reopen, and West Virginia has since registered five coronavirus outbreaks at churches. Starting July 7, face coverings will be required where social distance can’t be mantained.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Tanning salons; Massage parlors and spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Bowling alleys, pool halls, roller rinks; Casinos; Movie theaters; Amusement parks, fairs, festivals
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms, recreation centers; State parks, campgrounds; Pools

date_details: Did not have a statewide stay-at-home order.
status_details: Gov. Mark Gordon, a Republican, did not order Wyoming residents to stay home, and he began lifting restrictions on businesses May 1. However, Mr. Gordon recently extended restrictions on restaurants, bars and gyms until at least July 15.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, entertaiment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks
